nodes.text: A land price bubble can arise even when the observed housing rent-to-price ratio is non-vanishing or stationary
It is necessary to distinguish pure land rent from housing-structure rent when assessing bubbles in land or housing markets
We analyze a two-period overlapping-generations model with consumption good and housing service to study land bubbles
Household preferences are Cobb-Douglas U = beta_y log c_y + beta_o log c_o + beta_h log h with beta_y+beta_o+beta_h=1 and young consume housing when transitioning to old

Production: representative firm produces housing structure using construction material M and land X with production function F(M,X) homogeneous of degree one, differentiable, concave, and satisfying an Inada-type condition
Young budget and aggregate expenditure shares imply optimal expenditures (c_y, c_o/R, r h) = (beta_y e, beta_o e, beta_h e)
Using market clearing and optimal expenditures, equilibrium land price equals P_t = beta_o e_t (land price proportional to endowment of young)
There exists a unique equilibrium characterized by the first-order conditions and market clearing; a land bubble occurs iff the sum over time of FX/F(M_t,1) is finite

For the CES production function with elasticity of substitution sigma>1, there is a land bubble iff the sum over t of e_t^{1/sigma - 1} is finite; with positive economic growth (e_t grows geometrically) this condition holds and land bubbles inevitably emerge
Bubble Characterization Lemma: an asset price exhibits a bubble iff the infinite sum of dividend yield Dt/Pt is finite
Analytical derivation: land dividend Dt = (FX/FM)(M_t,1) and dividend yield Dt/Pt = (beta_h/beta_o) FX/F(M_t,1), so bubble condition reduces to summability of FX/F
Aggregate housing rent-to-price ratio r_t h_t / P_t is constant and equal to beta_h/beta_o even when a land bubble exists, because housing rent includes structure rent

Conclusion: Empirical stationarity of observed price-to-rent ratios for housing does not rule out existence of pure land bubbles; researchers must separate pure land rent from structure rent to assess bubbles
Empirical estimates suggest elasticity of substitution between land and non-land factors in housing is slightly above one, supporting the sigma>1 assumption used in examples
Model simplifications include perishable housing that fully depreciates each period and housing consumption timing assumptions that reduce dimensionality but are not essential
Existence and uniqueness of equilibrium rely on homogeneity, concavity, and the Inada-type condition ensuring a unique M_t solves the equilibrium condition F/FM(M_t,1)=beta_h e_t h_t
